quiz.title: Physics Grade 11: Forces on Horizontal Surfaces
quiz.subtitle: Unit 2 Quiz 2: Net Force, Friction & Connected Systems (10 Problems)
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: A 12 kg box is pulled along a horizontal floor by a rope at a 25° angle above horizontal. The tension is 50 N, and μₖ = 0.20. Find the acceleration.
A 5.0 kg block rests on a horizontal surface with μₛ = 0.40. What minimum horizontal force is needed to start it moving?
Two boxes connected by a string: 4.0 kg (A) pulled right with 30 N, 6.0 kg (B) attached, frictionless surface. Find tension in string.
questions.explanation: System acceleration: a = F/(m₁+m₂) = 30/10 = 3.0 m/s². Tension on B: T = m₂a = 6.0×3.0 = 18.0 N.

questions.question: A 15 kg crate is pushed with 60 N horizontally. μₖ = 0.25. Find acceleration.
A 20 kg sled pulled with 80 N at 30° above horizontal, μₖ = 0.15. Find acceleration.
An 8.0 kg block pushed against vertical wall with 40 N horizontal force. μₛ = 0.50. Will it slide down?
questions.explanation: Weight = 78.4 N. Max static friction = μₛN = 0.50×40 = 20 N. 20 N < 78.4 N, so friction insufficient → slides.

questions.question: Two stacked boxes: 3.0 kg on 7.0 kg, 25 N applied to bottom box. μₛ between boxes = 0.30, μₖ floor = 0.20. Find system acceleration if no slip.
questions.explanation: Floor friction = 0.20×10×9.8 = 19.6 N. Net = 25 - 19.6 = 5.4 N. a = 5.4/10 = 0.54 m/s². Check slip: force on top = 3×0.54 = 1.62 N < max static 8.82 N, so no slip.

questions.question: 10 kg box pulled: 40 N at 30° above horizontal right, 30 N at 20° below horizontal left, μₖ = 0.25. Find acceleration magnitude.
6.0 kg block, μₛ = 0.45, μₖ = 0.35. Force 20 N at 40° above horizontal applied. Does it move?
options: No, horizontal force < max static friction

questions.question: 25 kg box dragged with rope at 15° above horizontal. Motion starts at T = 120 N. What is μₛ?

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You've mastered forces on horizontal surfaces with friction.
scoreMessages.70: Very good! Solid understanding of net force and friction calculations.
scoreMessages.50: Good progress. Focus on free-body diagrams and force components.
